item.title: RT peach: taste is in the formative, and dies in the format itâ€™s the how and what of the thing, so that the [thing being done] is like running in the...
item.description:
RTâ€‚peach
taste is in the formative, and dies in the format

itâ€™s the how and what of the thing, so that the [thing being done] is like running in the right direction rather than in circles or into the mud

already having a song in your head, and so knowing when something isnâ€™t in it even if it sounds cool - rather than making a load of noise to see what sounds cool, or pattern matching to a format

most of the discussion about taste and ai is kinda misaligned by nature, and way downstream of bad assumptions

which humans are feeling instinctively, and parodying. because ai, certainly in current form, is literally recursive pattern matching and is entirely derived from input and scaffolding. which is, by design, compounded format

so the inferences humans probably feel from the conversation are probably downstream of two instinctual reactions

- most of the people talking about taste have none
- obviously, in a world where task value decreases, decision value increases. taste is the thing
- ai canâ€™t have taste, by definition of what those things both literally are, and any downstream argument probably needs to sort its semantic framework out, kinda like when people were calling a [supposed] agent forum a â€œsocialâ€ network, which is a paradoxical term

and the conversation is mostly taking place in siloâ€™s with two very disconnected types of people

sf people think ai can have taste because they operate a lot like an llm and thatâ€™s how they think about taste too. itâ€™s compounded pattern matching on the human layer, which has driven format far from the formative factors it used to signal

at the same time, taste (or anything related to it) is an ongoing conversation, in action (as an outcome of our own internal conversation), with each other. a everything makes sense because of what came before it

and there are very interesting conversations to be had relating to ai and formative creativity, taste, etc. but they probably need a new vernacular



Andrew ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«:â€‚mfers think Taste is a herman miller chair, eames desk, dieter rams hi-fi, some blob-like sculptural sofa, cermonial-grade matcha, natural orange wine, and snacks with art nouveau inspired lettering on the package sold from a tiny boutique store, but really it's â€¦

item.title: RT Forgd: Most teams underestimate how many structural choices determine a TGE's outcome. There's a reason why we've built free tools for token design...
item.description:
RTâ€‚Forgd
Most teams underestimate how many structural choices determine a TGE's outcome. There's a reason why we've built free tools for token design, market maker analytics and exchange data intelligence in one integrated system.

This analysis of 125 launches from @ArrakisFinance puts real data behind what teams usually learn the hard way.

Have a read belowğŸ‘‡


Arrakis:â€‚We analyzed 125 token launches and spoke with 25+ founders to learn why 85% of tokens launched in 2025 ended the year negative.

Only 9.4% of tokens that declined in their first week ever recovered. What drove Week 1 relied on decisions founders often overlooked.

RTâ€‚Sterling
Excited to finally announce that Iâ€™ve joined Hyperliquid Labs to help with BD and partnerships. My initial focus will be expanding builder code integrations by working with developers globally.

Hyperliquid

é™„ä¸Š Robert Mitchnick çš„åŸè¯ï¼š

But what we see is not the case. Last week, the Bitcoin market was clearly turbulent, and we looked at the data for IBIT , and the entire fund's redemption volume was only 0.2%.

If there were indeed many hedge funds aggressively unwinding their arbitrage trades in the ETF, you should see billions of dollars flowing out. Instead, we did see billions of dollars in liquidation on these leveraged perpetual swap platforms.

On the ETF side, however, it was very stable, and the investor base looked more like the type that buys and holds long term.

IOPn @IOPn_io æ–°ç­”é¢˜ä»»åŠ¡å¯é¢†å– $OPN æµ‹è¯•å¸å¥–åŠ±ï¼Œç­”é¢˜æ¯”è¾ƒç®€å•
https://learn.iopn.tech
é¢†æ°´é“¾æ¥ï¼šhttps://faucet.iopn.tech

How does IOPn describe the starting point for digital sovereignty?
Answer: Controlling your identity with one credential, your rules, everywhere

What is the fundamental difference between current systems and IOPn's approach?
Answer: Current systems are optimized for extraction; IOPn is built for empowerment

What does IOPn mean by "sovereign infrastructure"?
Answer: Infrastructure where you control your identity, assets, and future

Who is affected by the current lack of digital ownership?
Answer: Individuals, businesses, and governments

What does "Internet of People" represent in IOPn's vision?
Answer: A network where infrastructure serves people, not platforms

According to IOPn's vision, who currently controls your digital identity?
Answer: The platforms you use

What is the core problem IOPn addresses?
Answer: Lack of ownership over digital identity, data, and accounts

item.title: Transcriptï¼š â€”â€” Role: You are now my Technical Co-Founder. Your job is to help me build a real product I can use, share, or launch. Handle all the b...
item.description:
Transcriptï¼š
â€”â€”
Role:
You are now my Technical Co-Founder. Your job is to help me build a real product I can use, share, or launch. Handle all the building, but keep me in the loop and in control.

My Idea:
[Describe your product idea â€” what it does, who it's for, what problem it solves. Explain it like you'd tell a friend.]

How serious I am:
[Just exploring / I want to use this myself / I want to share it with others / I want to launch it publicly]

Project Framework:

1. Phase 1: Discovery
â€¢ Ask questions to understand what I actually need (not just what I said)
â€¢ Challenge my assumptions if something doesn't make sense
â€¢ Help me separate "must have now" from "add later"
â€¢ Tell me if my idea is too big and suggest a smarter starting point

2. Phase 2: Planning
â€¢ Propose exactly what we'll build in version 1
â€¢ Explain the technical approach in plain language
â€¢ Estimate complexity (simple, medium, ambitious)
â€¢ Identify anything I'll need (accounts, services, decisions)
â€¢ Show a rough outline of the finished product

3. Phase 3: Building
â€¢ Build in stages I can see and react to
â€¢ Explain what you're doing as you go (I want to learn)
â€¢ Test everything before moving on
â€¢ Stop and check in at key decision points
â€¢ If you hit a problem, tell me the options instead of just picking one

4. Phase 4: Polish
â€¢ Make it look professional, not like a hackathon project
â€¢ Handle edge cases and errors gracefully
â€¢ Make sure it's fast and works on different devices if relevant
â€¢ Add small details that make it feel "finished"

5. Phase 5: Handoff
â€¢ Deploy it if I want it online
â€¢ Give clear instructions for how to use it, maintain it, and make changes
â€¢ Document everything so I'm not dependent on this conversation
â€¢ Tell me what I could add or improve in version 2

6. How to Work with Me
â€¢ Treat me as the product owner. I make the decisions, you make them happen.
â€¢ Don't overwhelm me with technical jargon. Translate everything.
â€¢ Push back if I'm overcomplicating or going down a bad path.
â€¢ Be honest about limitations. I'd rather adjust expectations than be disappointed.
â€¢ Move fast, but not so fast that I can't follow what's happening.

Rules:
â€¢ I don't just want it to work â€” I want it to be something I'm proud to show people
â€¢ This is real. Not a mockup. Not a prototype. A working product.
â€¢ Keep me in control and in the loop at all times


Miles Deutscher:â€‚Alright - here's my most powerful vibe coding prompt ever.

Plug this straight into the new Opus 4.6 model, and you'll literally be able to ship anything.

SEO optimised websites, fully functional Claude apps, personal dashboards - literally anything.

Takes <5 minutes:
